d000.s000: Your Oct . 6 editorial `` The Ill Homeless '' referred to research by us and six of our colleagues that was reported in the Sept . 8 issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association .
d000.s001: Your comments implied we had discovered that the `` principal cause '' of homelessness is to be found in the large numbers of mentally ill and substance-abusing people in the homeless population .
d000.s002: We have made no such statement .
d000.s003: It is clear that most mentally ill people and most alcoholics do not become homeless .
d000.s004: The `` causes '' of homelessness are poorly understood and complex in any individual case .
d000.s005: In quoting from our research you emphasized the high prevalence of mental illness and alcoholism .
d000.s006: You did not note that the homeless people we examined had a multitude of physical disorders in addition to their psychiatric problems and substance abuse .
d000.s007: They suffered from malnutrition , chest diseases , cardiovascular disorders , skin problems , infectious diseases and the aftereffects of assaults and rape .
d000.s008: Homeless people not only lack safety , privacy and shelter , they also lack the elementary necessities of nutrition , cleanliness and basic health care .
d000.s009: In a recent report , the Institute of Medicine pointed out that certain health problems may predispose a person to homelessness , others may be a consequence of it , and a third category is composed of disorders whose treatment is difficult or impossible if a person lacks adequate shelter .
d000.s010: The interactions between health and homelessness are complex , defying sweeping generalizations as to `` cause '' or `` effect . ''
d000.s011: If we look to the future , preventing homelessness is an important objective .
d000.s012: This will require us to develop a much more sophisticated understanding of the dynamics of homelessness than we currently possess , an understanding that can be developed only through careful study and research .
d000.s013: William R . Breakey M . D . Pamela J . Fischer M . D . Department of Psychiatry Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine Baltimore
d000.s014: A study by Tulane Prof . James Wright says homelessness is due to a complex array of problems , with the common thread of poverty .
d000.s015: The study shows that nearly 40 % of the homeless population is made up of women and children and that only 25 % of the homeless exhibits some combination of drug , alcohol and mental problems .
d000.s016: According to Dr . Wright , homelessness is `` simultaneously a housing problem , an employment problem , a demographic problem , a problem of social disaffiliation , a mental health problem , a family violence problem , a problem created by the cutbacks in social welfare spending , a problem resulting from the decay of the traditional nuclear family , and a problem intimately connected to the recent increase in the number of persons living below the poverty level . ''
d000.s017: Leighton E . Cluff M . D . President Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Princeton , N . J .
d000.s018: To quote the highly regarded director of a privately funded drop-in center for the homeless in New York : `` If you 're homeless , you do n't sleep for fear of being robbed or murdered .
d000.s019: After your first three weeks of sleep deprivation , you 're scarcely in touch with reality any more ; without psychiatric treatment , you may well be unable to fend for yourself ever again . ''
d000.s020: Some of the homeless , obviously , had pre-existing mental illness or addiction .
d000.s021: But many others have fallen through cracks in the economy into the grim , brutal world of our city streets .
d000.s022: Once there , what ways of escape are open to them other than drink , drugs or insanity ?
d000.s023: Maxwell R . D . Vos Brooklyn , N . Y .
d000.s024: You dismiss as `` sentimental '' the view that the reduction of federal housing-assistance programs by 77 % might have played a significant role in the increased number of men and women sleeping on our city streets during the Reagan-Bush years .
d000.s025: There is no sign that you bothered to consider the inverse of your logic : namely , that mental illness and substance abuse might be to some degree consequences rather than causes of homelessness .
d000.s026: Your research stopped when a convenient assertion could be made .
d000.s028: Of the approximately 200 sponsors of the recent march in Washington for the homeless , you chose to cite such groups as the National Association of Home Builders and the International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftsmen , insinuating that the march got its major support from self-serving groups that `` know a good thing when they see it , '' and that the crusade was based on greed or the profit motive .
d000.s029: But is n't the desire for profit the driving force behind those who subscribe to , and advertise in , your paper ?
d000.s030: Why did n't you mention the YMCA or the YWCA or Catholic Charities USA or a hundred other nonprofit organizations that participated in the march ?
d000.s031: As for the findings on the 203 Baltimore homeless who underwent psychiatric examinations , I suggest you conduct your own survey .
d000.s032: Choose 203 business executives , including , perhaps , someone from your own staff , and put them out on the streets , to be deprived for one month of their homes , families and income .
d000.s033: I would predict that within a short time most of them would find Thunderbird a satisfactory substitute for Chivas Regal and that their `` normal '' phobias , anxieties , depressions and substance abuse would increase dramatically .
d000.s034: Ruth K . Nelson Cullowhee , N . C .
d001.s000: `` Feeding Frenzy '' ( Henry Holt , 326 pages , $ 19 . 95 ) , a highly detailed account of the Wedtech scandal , begins on a reassuring note .
d001.s001: Right up front in the preface , co-author William Sternberg gives us an example of his own integrity .
d001.s002: When offered a free trip from the Bronx , Wedtech 's home , to Washington , D . C . , by one of Wedtech 's principals , he tells the reader , `` mindful of accepting anything of value from those I was writing about , I declined . ''
d001.s003: Any question as to why an author would believe this plaintive , high-minded note of assurance is necessary is answered by reading this book about sticky fingers and sweaty scammers .
d001.s004: Bribe by bribe , Mr . Sternberg and his co-author , Matthew C . Harrison Jr . , lead us along the path Wedtech traveled , from its inception as a small manufacturing company to the status of full-fledged defense contractor , entrusted with the task of producing vital equipment for the Army and Navy .
d001.s005: The book revolves around John Mariotta , the founder of the company , and Fred Neuberger , who became his partner soon after Wedtech 's creation .
d001.s006: Although started in 1965 , Wedtech did n't really get rolling until 1975 , when Mr . Neuberger discovered the federal government 's Section 8 ( A ) minority business program .
d001.s007: This is a Johnson- era , Great Society creation that mandates certain government contracts be awarded noncompetitively to minority businesses .
d001.s008: Mr . Neuberger realized that , although of Italian ancestry , Mr . Mariotta still could qualify as a minority person since he was born in Puerto Rico .
d001.s009: The two partners merely had to falsify the true ownership of the corporation .
d001.s010: Instead of 50/50 it became , on paper only , two-thirds Mariotta , one-third Neuberger , and they were in the program and off to the races .
d001.s011: Besides being a `` minority-owned company '' Wedtech was located in the South Bronx , a blighted area , made famous by Jimmy Carter in his 1976 presidential campaign .
d001.s012: The company plugged itself right into Carter campaign rhetoric about rebuilding the South Bronx and kept using the minority -- South Bronx angle through the Reagan '80s .
d001.s013: Starting with Congressman Mario Biaggi ( now serving a jail sentence ) , the company began a career of bribing federal , state and local public officials and those close to public officials , right up to and including E . Robert Wallach , close friend and adviser to former Attorney General Ed Meese .
d001.s014: Wedtech did n't just use old fashioned bribery .
d001.s015: It made ample use of the modern techniques of influence peddling , retaining politically connected `` respectable '' law firms , investment bankers and political consultants , including Reagan confidant Lyn Nofzinger .
d001.s016: When necessary , it sought and received assistance from organized crime .
d001.s017: Sometimes the bribed became partners in the company .
d001.s018: Wedtech management used the merit system .
d001.s019: If you were especially helpful in a corrupt scheme you received not just cash in a bag , but equity .
d001.s020: If you were not an effective crook , you found yourself out in the cold , a fate that eventually befell Mr . Mariotta , the firm 's semiliterate `` minority '' person .
d001.s021: But despite the sensational nature of the revelations and the breezy , easy-to-read tabloid writing style , `` Feeding Frenzy '' often falls short of gripping reading .
d001.s022: None of the scams show much ingenuity : Auditors found crookery the first day on the job .
d001.s023: Wedtech 's scammers simply bribed them to shut up .
d001.s024: The scammers themselves were garden-variety low lifes , conspicuous consumers who wanted big houses , Mercedes cars , beautiful women , expensive clothes .
d001.s025: Among the lot of them , not one is wrestling with good and evil , or especially intelligent or even temporarily insane .
d001.s026: The one character at least somewhat interesting was Irving Louis Lobsenz , a pediatrician who changed his name to Rusty Kent London and became a master gambler and author of a book on blackjack .
d001.s027: He enters the story toward the end , just in time to get arrested .
d001.s028: Absorbed in doling out `` Feeding Frenzy 's '' tidbits , the authors gloss over the root causes of Wedtech , namely the Section 8 ( A ) federal program under whose auspices the scandal took place .
d001.s029: They do at least come around to saying that the courts might want to end `` rigid affirmative action programs . ''
d001.s030: Programs like Section 8 ( A ) are a little like leaving gold in the street and then expressing surprise when thieves walk by to scoop it up .
d001.s031: Numerous other scandals , among them the ones at HUD , have the same characteristics as Wedtech .
d001.s032: They take place in government programs that seem tailor-made for corruption .
d001.s033: Why are programs like this not eliminated ?
d001.s034: `` Feeding Frenzy '' does provide a few clues .
d001.s035: In and around all levels of government in the U . S . are groups of people who can best be described as belonging to a political insider commercial party .
d001.s036: They know that whenever government is redistributing wealth , regulating commerce or maintaining a large defense establishment , there is big money to be made in influencing , brokering or selling the processes and decisions of government .
d001.s037: They are our version of the East bloc 's Nomenklatura and they have absolutely no wish to see anything change .
d001.s038: How many government programs and policies exist because they line the pockets of political insiders ?
d001.s039: This is the real issue raised by the Wedtech scandal .
d001.s040: Mr . Stern was chairman and chief executive officer of the New York State Urban Development Corp . , 1983-85 .
d002.s000: I had to reach back to French 101 when the monsieur avec clipboard leaned over my shoulder during the coffee phase of dinner and asked whether I wanted to ride in a montgolfiere .
d002.s001: I was a last-minute ( read interloping ) attendee at a French journalism convention and so far the festivities had been taken up entirely by eating , drinking , smoking , sleeping and drinking .
d002.s002: The man with the clipboard represented a halfhearted attempt to introduce a bit of les sportif into our itinerary .
d002.s003: But as the French embody a Zen-like state of blase when it comes to athletics ( try finding a Nautilus machine in Paris ) , my fellow conventioners were having none of it .
d002.s004: The diners at my table simply lit more Gauloises and scoffed at the suggestion of interrupting a perfectly good Saturday morning to go golfing or even montgolfing ( ballooning to you ; the brothers Montgolfier , French of course , were the world 's first hot-air balloonists ) .
d002.s005: Back in the U . S . A . this kind of chi-chi airborne activity wins heartwarmingly covetous responses .
d002.s008: Americans it seems have followed Malcolm Forbes 's hot-air lead and taken to ballooning in a heady way .
d002.s009: During the past 25 years , the number of balloonists ( those who have passed a Federal Aviation Authority lighter-than-air test ) have swelled from a couple hundred to several thousand , with some estimates running as high as 10 , 000 .
d002.s010: Some 30 balloon shows are held annually in the U . S . , including the world 's largest convocation of ersatz Phineas Foggs -- the nine-day Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta that attracts some 800 , 000 enthusiasts and more than 500 balloons , some of which are fetchingly shaped to resemble Carmen Miranda , Garfield or a 12-story-high condom .
d002.s011: ( The condom balloon was denied official entry status this year . )
d002.s012: But in Epinal , a gray 16th-century river town adjacent to France 's Vosges mountain region , none of these Yankee-come-lately enthusiasms for things aloft was evident .
d002.s013: Ballooning at the de rigueur hour of 6 a . m . held all the attraction for most people of sunrise root-canal work .
d002.s014: Feeling the naggings of a culture imperative , I promptly signed up .
d002.s015: The first thing anybody will tell you about ballooning is that it requires zip in the way of athletic prowess , or even a measure of derring-do .
d002.s016: ( So long as you do n't look down . )
d002.s017: They will also tell you that even if you hate heights , you can still balloon .
d002.s018: ( I still say do n't look down .
d002.s019: At least not when you are ascending . )
d002.s020: What they wo n't tell you is not to go aloft in anything you do n't want to get wet .
d002.s021: I 'm not referring to the traditional champagne drenching during the back-on-terra-firma toast .
d002.s022: I 'm talking about landing in a canal .
d002.s024: With a pilot who speaks no English .
d002.s025: To wit , my maiden voyage ( and novitiates are referred to as virgins ) began at dawn on a dew-sodden fairway and ended at noon in a soggy field .
d002.s026: ( Balloon flights almost always occur at dawn or dusk , when the winds are lightest . )
d002.s027: In between came lots of coffee drinking while watching the balloons inflate and lots of standing around deciding who would fly in what balloon and in what order ( the baskets hold no more than four passengers ) .
d002.s028: When it was n't my turn in the balloon I followed its progress from the `` chase car , '' listening to the driver holler into a walkie-talkie .
d002.s029: After long stretches of this attendant ground activity came 20 or so lovely minutes of drifting above the Vosges watching the silver mists rise off the river and the French cows amble about the fields .
d002.s030: It 's hard not to feel that God 's in his heaven with this kind of bird's-eye view of the world , even if your pilote in silly plaid beret kept pointing out how `` belle '' it all was .
d002.s031: Eventually little French farmers and their little French farmwives came out of their stone houses and put their hands above their tiny eyes and squinted at us .
d002.s033: We were coming down straight into their canal .
d002.s034: See , the other rule of thumb about ballooning is that you ca n't steer .
d002.s036: You can go only up or down ( by heating the balloon 's air with a propane burner , which does make the top of your head feel hot ) and ride the air currents .
d002.s037: Which makes the chase car necessary .
d002.s038: Most balloonists seldom go higher than 2 , 000 feet and most average a leisurely 5-10 miles an hour .
d002.s039: When the balloon is cruising along at a steady altitude there is little sense of motion .
d002.s040: Only when one is ascending -- or in our case descending a tad trop rapidement -- does one feel , well , airborne in a picnic basket .
d002.s041: `` What 's he doing ? '' hissed my companion , who was the only other English-speaking member of the convention and whose knuckles were white .
d002.s042: `` Attention , '' yelled our pilot as our basket plunged into the canal .
d002.s043: `` You bet attention , '' I yelled back , leaping atop the propane tanks , `` I 'm wearing alligator loafers ! ''
d002.s044: Our pilot simply laughed , fired up the burner and with another blast of flame lifted us , oh , a good 12-inches above the water level .
d002.s045: We scuttled along for a few feet before he plunged us into the drink again .
d002.s046: Eventually we came to rest in a soggy patch of field where we had the exquisite pleasure of scrambling out of the basket into the mud while the French half of our ballooning tag team scrambled in .
d002.s049: Back in the chase car , we drove around some more , got stuck in a ditch , enlisted the aid of a local farmer to get out the trailer hitch and pull us out of the ditch .
d002.s050: We finally rendezvoused with our balloon , which had come to rest on a dirt road amid a clutch of Epinalers who watched us disassemble our craft -- another half-an-hour of non-flight activity -- that included the precision routine of yanking the balloon to the ground , punching all the air out of it , rolling it up and cramming it and the basket into the trailer .
d002.s051: It was the most exercise we 'd had all morning and it was followed by our driving immediately to the nearest watering hole .
d002.s052: This meant returning to the golf course , where we watched a few French duffers maul the first tee while we sat under Cinzano umbrellas , me nursing an espresso and my ego .
d002.s053: A whole morning of ballooning and I had been off the ground barely 30 minutes .
d002.s054: Still , I figured the event 's envy-quotient back in the U . S . A . was near peerless .
d002.s055: As for the ride back to camp , our pilot and all the other French-speaking passengers clambered into the chase car .
d002.s056: My American companion and I were left to ride alfresco in the wicker basket .
d002.s057: As we streaked by a blase gendarme , I could n't resist rearing up on my soggy loafers and saluting .
d002.s058: Ms . de Vries is a free-lance writer .
d003.s001: Computer programming ( often shortened to programming or coding ) is the process of writing , testing , and maintaining the source code of computer programs .
d003.s002: The source code is written in a programming language .
d003.s003: This code may be a modification of existing source or something completely new .
d003.s004: The process of writing source code requires expertise in many different subjects , including knowledge of the application domain and algorithms to implement the desired behavior .
d003.s005: Within software engineering , programming ( the implementation ) is regarded as one phase in a software development process .
d003.s006: In some specialist applications or extreme situations a program may be written or modified ( known as patching ) by directly storing the numeric values of the machine code instructions to be executed into memory .
d003.s007: There is an ongoing debate on the extent to which the writing of programs is an art , a craft or an engineering discipline . [1]
d003.s008: Another ongoing debate is the extent to which the programming language used in writing programs affects the form that the final program takes .
d003.s009: This debate is analogous to that surrounding the Sapir Whorf hypothesis in linguistics .
d003.s011: Computer programmers are those who write computer software .
d003.s012: Their job usually involves : Requirements analysis , Specification , Software architecture , Coding , Compilation , Software testing , Documentation , Integration , Maintenance .
d003.s014: Different programming languages support different styles of programming ( called programming paradigms ) .
d003.s015: The choice of language used may be an individual 's choice or may be dictated by company policy .
d003.s016: Ideally the programming language best suited for the task at hand will be selected .
d003.s017: Trade-offs from this ideal involve finding enough programmers , who know the language , to build a team , the availability of compilers for that language , and the efficiency with which programs written in a given language execute .
d003.s019: The earliest programmable machine ( that is , a machine that can adjust its capabilities based upon changing its '' program '' ) can be said to be the Jacquard Loom , which was developed in 1801 .
d003.s020: The machine used a series of pasteboard cards with holes punched in them .
d003.s021: The hole pattern represented the pattern that the loom had to follow in weaving cloth .
d003.s022: The loom could produce entirely different weaves using different sets of cards .
d003.s023: This innovation was later refined by Herman Hollerith of IBM in the development of the famous IBM punch card .
d003.s024: These were used with a variety of machines called unit record equipment to perform data processing tasks .
d003.s025: The unit record equipment were programmed by changing the wiring of plugboards .
d003.s026: Early computers used similar programming methods .
d003.s027: The invention of the Von Neumann architecture allowed programs to be stored in computer memory .
d003.s028: Early programs had to be painstakingly crafted using the instructions of the particular machine , often in binary notation .
d003.s029: Every model of computer would be likely to need different instructions to do the same task .
d003.s030: Later assembly languages were developed that let the programmer specify each instruction in a text format , entering abbreviations for each operation code instead of a number and specifying addresses in symbolic form ( e . g . ADD X , TOTAL ) .
d003.s031: In 1954 Fortran , the first higher level programming language , was invented .
d003.s032: This allowed programmers to specify calculations by entering a formula directly ( e . g . Y = X*2 + 5*X + 9 ) .
d003.s033: The program text , or source , was converted into machine instructions using a special program called a compiler .
d003.s034: Many other languages were developed , including ones for commercial programming , such as COBOL .
d003.s035: Programs were mostly still entered using punch cards or paper tape .
d003.s036: ( See computer programming in the punch card era ) .
d003.s037: In the mid-1970s , mass storage devices and computer terminals became inexpensive enough so programs could be created by typing directly into the computers .
d003.s038: Text editors were developed that allowed changes and corrections to be made much more easily than with punch cards .
d003.s039: As time has progressed computers have made giant leaps in the area of processing power .
d003.s040: This has brought about newer programming languages that are more abstracted from the underlying hardware .
d003.s041: Although these more abstracted languages require additional overhead , in most cases the huge increase in speed of modern computers has brought about little performance decrease compared to earlier counterparts .
d003.s042: The benefits of these more abstracted languages is that they allow both an easier learning curve for people less familiar with the older lower-level programming languages , and they also allow a more experienced programmer to develop simple applications quickly .
d003.s043: Despite these benefits , large complicated programs , and programs that are more dependent on speed still require the faster and relatively lower-level languages with todays hardware .
d003.s044: ( The same concerns were raised about the original Fortran language . )
d003.s045: Throughout the second half of the twentieth century , programming was an attractive career in most developed countries .
d003.s046: Some forms of programming have been increasingly subject to offshore outsourcing ( importing software and services from other countries , usually at a lower wage ) , making programming career decisions in developed countries more complicated , while increasing economic opportunities in less developed areas .
d003.s047: It is unclear how far this trend will continue and how deeply it will impact programmer wages and opportunities .
d003.s048: Despite the '' outsourcing trend '' it can be argued that some of the richest persons on the globe are programmers by profession .
d003.s049: Examples : Bill Gates ( Microsoft ) , Larry Ellison ( Oracle ) , Larry Page ( Google ) , Hasso Plattner ( SAP ) and so on .
d003.s050: Programming is clearly a leading-edge craftsmanship that continues to reward its practitioners both in countries such as India and developed countries like the USA or Germany .
d003.s053: The first step in every software development project should be requirements analysis , followed by modeling , implementation and failure elimination ( debugging ) .
d003.s054: There exist a lot of differing approaches for each of those tasks ; with the most popular modeling technique being Object-Oriented Analysis and Design ( OOAD ) and Model-Driven Architecture ( MDA ) .
d003.s055: The Unified Modeling language ( UML ) is a notation used for OOAD .
d003.s056: A similar technique used for database design is Entity-Relationship Modeling ( ER Modeling ) .
d003.s057: Implementation techniques include imperative languages ( object-oriented or procedural ) , functional languages and logic languages .
d003.s058: Debugging is most often done with IDEs like Visual Studio , and Eclipse .
d003.s059: Separate debuggers like gdb are also used .
d003.s061: The most popular programming languages in the 21st century are C , C++ , C sharp , Cobol , Fortran , Java , PHP and Python .
d003.s062: Many languages have evolved from C , such as C++ , , and Java .
d003.s063: Java , and Python are popular because programs written in them are executed in a virtual machine , avoiding many of the problems of lower-level languages such as C , C++ or Assembler , such as buffer overruns and invalid pointers .
d003.s064: However , most PC desktop applications such as word processors or image manipulation programs are written in more runtime and memory efficient languages like C , C++ , and Delphi .
d003.s065: Operating systems are almost exclusively written in low-level programming languages like C , C++ , or Assembler , since speed is necessary in components like context switching , process and thread management , and memory management .
d003.s066: Scientific applications are often implemented in Fortran because very efficient optimization ( using optimizing Compilers ) is possible for arithmetic .
d003.s067: Cobol is still very strong in the corporate data center , mainly on large Mainframe computers .
d003.s068: PHP and Java excel in database-oriented applications which are often delivered over the internet or corporate intranets .
d003.s069: Python , while being a general-purpose programming language , is mostly used in system administration and web programming .
d003.s071: Debugging is a very important task for every programmer , because an erroneous program is often useless .
d003.s072: Languages like C++ and Assembler are very challenging even to expert programmers because of failure modes like Buffer overruns , bad pointers or uninitialized memory .
d003.s073: A buffer overrun can damage adjacent memory regions and cause a failure in a totally different program line .
d003.s074: Because of those memory issues tools like Valgrind , Purify or Boundschecker are virtually a necessity for modern software development in the C++ language .
d003.s075: Languages such as Java , PHP and Python protect the programmer from most of these runtime failure modes , but this comes at the price of a dramatically lower execution speed of the resulting program .
d004.s001: It must have been about the same time when Fra Angelico was covering the walls of San Marco with his angel pictures , that a very different kind of painter was working in the Carmine church in Florence .
d004.s002: This was no gentle , refined monk , but just an ordinary man of the world an awkward , good-natured person , who , as long as he had pictures to paint , cared for little else .
d004.s003: Why , he would even forget to ask for payment when his work was done ; and as to taking care of his clothes , or trying to keep himself tidy , that was a thing he never thought of !
d004.s004: What trouble his mother must have had with him when he was a boy !
d004.s005: It was no use sending him on an errand , he would forget it before he had gone a hundred yards , and he was so careless and untidy that it was enough to make any one lose patience with him .
d004.s006: But only let him have a pencil and a smooth surface on which to draw , and he was a different boy .
d004.s007: It is said that even now , in the little town of Castello San Giovanni , some eighteen miles from Florence , where Tommaso was born , there are still some wonderfully good figures to be seen , drawn by him when he was quite a little boy .
d004.s008: Certainly there was no carelessness and nothing untidy about his work .
d004.s009: As the boy grew older all his longings would turn towards Florence , the beautiful city where there was everything to learn and to see , and so he was sent to become a pupil in the studio of Masolino , a great Florentine painter .
d004.s010: But though his drawings improved , his careless habits continued the same .
d004.s011: ` There goes Tommaso the painter , ' the people would say , watching the big awkward figure passing through the streets on his way to work .
d004.s012: ` Truly he pays but little heed to his appearance .
d004.s013: Look but at his untidy hair and the holes in his boots . '
d004.s015: ` and yet it is said if only people paid him all they owed he would have gold enough and to spare .
d004.s016: But what cares he so long as he has his paints and brushes ?
d004.s017: `` Masaccio '' would be a fitter name for him than Tommaso . '
d004.s018: So the name Masaccio , or Ugly Tom , came to be that by which the big awkward painter was known .
d004.s019: But no one thinks of the unkind meaning of the nickname now , for Masaccio is honoured as one of the great names in the history of Art .
d004.s020: This painter , careless of many things , cared with all his heart and soul for the work he had chosen to do .
d004.s021: It seemed to him that painters had always failed to make their pictures like living things .
d004.s022: The pictures they painted were flat , not round as a figure should be , and very often the feet did not look as if they were standing on the ground at all , but pointed downwards as if they were hanging in the air .
d004.s023: So he worked with light and shadow and careful drawing until the figures he drew looked rounded instead of flat , and their feet were planted firmly on the ground .
d004.s024: His models were taken from the ordinary Florentine youths whom he saw daily in the studio , but he drew them as no one had drawn figures before .
d004.s025: The buildings , too , he made to look like real houses leading away into the distance , and not just like a flat picture .
d004.s026: He painted many frescoes both in Florence and Rome , this Ugly Tom , but at the time the people did not pay him much honour , for they thought him just a great awkward fellow with his head always in the clouds .
d004.s027: Perhaps if he had lived longer fame and wealth would have come to him , but he died when he was still a young man , and only a few realised how great he was .
d004.s028: But in after years , one by one , all the great artists would come to that little chapel of the Carmine there to learn their first lessons from those life-like figures .
d004.s029: Especially they would stand before the fresco which shows St . Peter baptizing a crowd of people .
d004.s030: And in that fresco they would study more than all the figure of a boy who has just come out of the water , shivering with cold , the most natural figure that had ever been painted up to that time .
d004.s031: All things must be learnt little by little , and each new thing we know is a step onwards .
d004.s032: So this figure of the shivering boy marks a higher step of the golden ladder of Art than any that had been touched before .
d004.s033: And this alone would have made the name of Masaccio worthy to be placed upon the list of world 's great painters .
